verses.verse: Is there not an appointed time<WH6635> to man<WH582> upon earth<WH776>? are not his days<WH3117> also like the days<WH3117> of an hireling<WH7916>? an appointed: or, a warfare
As a servant<WH5650> earnestly desireth<WH7602> the shadow<WH6738>, and as an hireling<WH7916> looketh<WH6960> for the reward of his work<WH6467>: earnestly: Heb. gapeth after
So am I made to possess<WH5157> months<WH3391> of vanity<WH7723>, and wearisome<WH5999> nights<WH3915> are appointed<WH4487> to me.

When I lie down<WH7901>, I say<WH559>, When shall I arise<WH6965>, and the night<WH6153> be gone<WH4059>? and I am full<WH7646> of tossings to and fro<WH5076> unto the dawning of the day<WH5399>. the night: Heb. the evening be measured?
My flesh<WH1320> is clothed<WH3847> with worms<WH7415> and clods<WH1487> of dust<WH6083>; my skin<WH5785> is broken<WH7280>, and become loathsome<WH3988>.
My days<WH3117> are swifter<WH7043> than a weaver's shuttle<WH708>, and are spent<WH3615> without<WH657> hope<WH8615>.
O remember<WH2142> that my life<WH2416> is wind<WH7307>: mine eye<WH5869> shall no more<WH7725> see<WH7200> good<WH2896>. shall: Heb. shall not return see: to see, that is, to enjoy
The eye<WH5869> of him that hath seen<WH7210> me shall see<WH7789> me no more: thine eyes<WH5869> are upon me, and I am not. I am: that is, I can live no longer
As the cloud<WH6051> is consumed<WH3615> and vanisheth away<WH3212>: so he that goeth down<WH3381> to the grave<WH7585> shall come up<WH5927> no more.
He shall return<WH7725> no more to his house<WH1004>, neither shall his place<WH4725> know<WH5234> him any more.
Therefore I will not refrain<WH2820> my mouth<WH6310>; I will speak<WH1696> in the anguish<WH6862> of my spirit<WH7307>; I will complain<WH7878> in the bitterness<WH4751> of my soul<WH5315>.
Am I a sea<WH3220>, or a whale<WH8577>, that thou settest<WH7760> a watch<WH4929> over me?
When I say<WH559>, My bed<WH6210> shall comfort<WH5162> me, my couch<WH4904> shall ease<WH5375> my complaint<WH7879>;
Then thou scarest<WH2865> me with dreams<WH2472>, and terrifiest<WH1204> me through visions<WH2384>:
So that my soul<WH5315> chooseth<WH977> strangling<WH4267>, and death<WH4194> rather than my life<WH6106>. life: Heb. bones
I loathe<WH3988> it; I would not live<WH2421> alway<WH5769>: let me alone<WH2308>; for my days<WH3117> are vanity<WH1892>.
What is man<WH582>, that thou shouldest magnify<WH1431> him? and that thou shouldest set<WH7896> thine heart<WH3820> upon him?
And that thou shouldest visit<WH6485> him every morning<WH1242>, and try<WH974> him every moment<WH7281>?
How long<WH4100> wilt thou not depart<WH8159> from me, nor let me alone<WH7503> till I swallow down<WH1104> my spittle<WH7536>?
I have sinned<WH2398>; what shall I do<WH6466> unto thee, O thou preserver<WH5341> of men<WH120>? why hast thou set<WH7760> me as a mark<WH4645> against thee, so that I am a burden<WH4853> to myself?

And why dost thou not pardon<WH5375> my transgression<WH6588>, and take away<WH5674> mine iniquity<WH5771>? for now shall I sleep<WH7901> in the dust<WH6083>; and thou shalt seek me in the morning<WH7836>, but I shall not be.
